hawaiian_text: Noho ihola i laila, mahi ‘ai, ‘elua āna mau māla  ‘uala lō‘ihi e waiho nei ā hiki i kēia lā, a ua kapa ‘ia  ka inoa o ia mau māla, ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i  kēia lā. A o‘o ka ‘uala, ‘ōlelo ‘o Puali‘i i kāna ‘ōlelo   ho‘ohiki, “Aia ā kālua ke po‘o o ka ulua me ka ‘uala,  a ‘ai ‘o Puali‘i, a laila, noa, ‘ai kāna wahine, Pōka‘ī a  me nā mea ‘ē a‘e. No laila, iho akula ‘o Puali‘i i kai  o Honouliuli e lawai‘a i i‘a ‘ai pū me ka ‘uala.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_translation: He stayed there, farming, and he had two long taro patches that remain to this day, and the names of those patches are known as Nāmakaokapāo‘o to this day. And when the taro matured, Puali‘i said in his oath, "When the head of the ulua fish and the taro are cooked, Puali‘i will eat, and then it will be free from kapu, and his wife, Pōka‘ī, and others will eat. Therefore, Puali‘i went down to the sea at Honouliuli to fish for fish to eat together with the taro.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_commentary:
The passage is rich in cultural, historical, and linguistic significance, offering insights into traditional Hawaiian practices, the importance of 'āina (land), and the spiritual and social protocols of ancient Hawaiian society.

Culturally, the passage highlights the significance of farming and fishing in Hawaiian subsistence practices. The mention of 'elua āna mau māla 'uala lō'ihi (two long taro patches) underscores the importance of taro ('uala) as a staple crop in Hawaiian agriculture and diet. Taro was not only a primary food source but also held spiritual and cultural significance, being associated with the god Kāne and considered a symbol of fertility and prosperity.

The naming of the taro patches as Nāmakaokapāo‘o indicates the practice of giving names to significant geographical or agricultural features, a common tradition in Hawaiian culture that connects people to the land and their ancestors. The persistence of the name "to this day" (ā hiki i kēia lā) suggests a continuity of cultural practices and memory.

The passage also illustrates the kapu system, a complex set of spiritual and social rules that governed ancient Hawaiian life. Puali‘i's 'ōlelo ho‘ohiki (oath or vow) establishes a kapu on the taro and fish until he has eaten, after which it becomes noa (free from kapu), allowing others, including his wife Pōka‘ī, to partake in the meal. This highlights the hierarchical and spiritual dimensions of food consumption in ancient Hawaii, where certain individuals, often of higher rank or spiritual significance, would eat first, and the act of eating was imbued with ritual and social protocol.

Linguistically, the passage is characterized by the use of classical Hawaiian vocabulary and grammatical structures. The text employs a formal, somewhat archaic style, reflective of the language used in traditional narratives and historical accounts. The use of specific terms like 'ōlelo ho‘ohiki for an oath or vow and the distinction between kapu and noa demonstrate the nuanced understanding of spiritual and social concepts in the Hawaiian language.

Historically, the passage provides a glimpse into the pre-contact or early contact period Hawaiian society, highlighting practices related to agriculture, fishing, and the kapu system. The specific location mentioned, Honouliuli, is an area on the island of O'ahu, indicating that the narrative is grounded in a particular geographical context, potentially linking the story to actual historical or legendary events or figures.

The narrative also reflects the interdependence of land and sea resources in Hawaiian subsistence strategies, as Puali‘i goes fishing to complement the taro from his patches. This interdependence is a recurring theme in Hawaiian cultural practices and is reflective of a broader ecological understanding that integrates human activity with the natural environment.

Overall, the passage is a valuable window into the cultural, historical, and linguistic practices of ancient Hawaii, offering insights into the daily life, spiritual beliefs, and social structures of Hawaiian society before significant external influences altered its trajectory.

reference_translation: They lived there and farmed, and Puali‘i had two  long sweet potato patches that remain until today,  and the patches were given the name,   Nāmakaokapāo‘o until today. When the sweet  potatoes were mature, Puali‘i said made a  promise, saying, “I’ll cook the head of an ulua fish  in the imu along with some sweet potatoes. When  Puali‘i eats, then the food will be made free for his  woman, Pōka‘ī, and anyone else.” So, Puali‘i went  down to the shore of Honouliuli to fish for a catch  to eat with sweet potatoes.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 4:**• Pua-li‘i is a farmer with 2 long sweet potato patches  that lasted until the publication of this story. The  name of this sweet potato garden was known as *Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o*, the name of Pō-ka-‘ī’s son, and  victorious hero of the story;  • When the sweet potatoes were ready for harvest,  Pua-li‘i said that when he eats ulua fish with sweet  potatoes, cooked in the imu. The food would then be  made free for others, particularly Pō-ka-‘ī and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o after he eats.  – The emphasis on Pua-li‘i, a male and head of the  family, eating, with his woman and child being  allowed to eat separately after he was done, is a  custom of ‘Ai Kapu culture;  • Having announced the eating routine/schedule, Pua li‘i then went to Hono-uliuli (dark bay) to fish for  ulua.  – The choice of ulua to eat with the ‘uala (sweet  potato) is likely due to the similarity in the   pronunciation of the two words, signifying ʻwhat is  above, so below,’ an old and recurring esoteric  feature of Hawaiian prosidy and culture, with a  lesson that there should always be balance in life  and in human practices (above-below; left-right;  male-female). This is the essence of ʻpono’;
